text: well it's really nice to be here I
thought a lot about what I want to talk
about and I've been a venture capitalist
off and on for 15 years and one of the
things that struck me when I thought
about what I wanted to cover today is
that while the technology infrastructure
that many of you are using the build
your startups has changed the advice
that we as VCS give you really hasn't it
really hasn't kept up with what some of
these technologies technological changes
have enabled so I wanted to give you one
person's perspective on new ways to
think about startups if you're getting
started today so when I think about when
I started my venture career in the late
90s there was a really simple playbook
for how you built the company if you
were ambitious you went and bought a
bunch of hardware and found a Colo space
and set everything up yourself it was
really expensive thanks to our hosts at
Amazon none of you need to do that
anymore so we should give them a round
of applause for making that part of the
process much easier but the thing I
really want to touch on today is when I
got started in venture in the late 90s
early 2000s there was this real ethos
that everyone needed to be in the same
room in the same place in order to build
a highly successful startup and over the
last 10 or 15 years having done a few
startups myself having advised and
invested in over a hundred companies I
no longer believed that all the things
that we've been telling startups for a
long time are true so I want to run
through a handful of things that at
least I as an investor I'm reconsidering
when I think about my own investment
criteria at precurser and a lot of these
are things I've learned from working
with companies that I backed and seeing
them succeed in ways that maybe
previously weren't possible so that old
formally was you you rack and sack your
own servers you build the team it better
be in the Bay Area if you were serious
regardless of cost you build that
product and find customers you go raise
venture capital money then you IPO and
succeed and you start over again I
really do think that times have changed
and the advice hasn't kept up so let's
dive into a couple of things that I
think are different so I think at the
fundamental basis for why all the
changes happen is that the cost equation
for startups has changed this is
probably not news to people in the room
but the thing I'd like to highlight is I
think a lot of the cost equation
conversation
has really been on the technical
infrastructure level it's cheaper to get
started you can turn AWS on and get
going from day one but there are a lot
of other elements of the cost equation
of running a startup that have also
changed that I don't think we've
explored as much and I think on the one
hand operating costs in some of the
major metros have gotten a lot more
expensive and as our previous speaker
mentioned Portland is a good safety
valve at the the prices at San Francisco
and New York are getting to you and I
think but more importantly and probably
less well discussed the cost of
collaboration and coordination which
isn't a financial cost but it's a tax
your organization pays I think that cost
has come way down and it's finally come
down enough that I think you can think
creatively about where you put people
and what you ask them to do so I think
what I'm seeing across my portfolio a
precursor is a true decline in
centralized teams just to give you some
perspective our first fund we've
invested in 81 companies 55 of them are
based here in the Bay Area but even the
ones who are based here in the Bay Area
many of them have development teams
sales operations one or two remote folks
that are based somewhere else and in
some cases that's due to cost and in
some cases that's due to the personal
preference of that person and I want to
talk a little bit about sort of what
I've seen happening and I think that it
was a real logic to the old narrative
about why you wanted everyone in one
place it was just way easier to build
culture if you have everybody in one
office in one place in one location you
get water cooler conversation you get
that sort of hallway talk people can see
each other and communicate face-to-face
it made communication easier and frankly
who here tried to use video conferencing
or even like a good dialing number in
late 90s early 2000s it was expensive
and it was a pretty miserable experience
and trying to run a company on that
infrastructure probably wasn't worth it
but when I think about what's happening
today we have tons of good tools for
teamwork both within the four walls of
your company and with partners whether
that's slack or zoom or video
conferencing video conference solution
of your choice I think it's really easy
to get online everywhere and it's it's
kind of funny to think that 10 or 15
years you couldn't presuppose that you
could get
good Wireless just cellular coverage
wherever you went and last but not least
I think as more teams run these
experiments with having people outside
of HQ the knowledge base of how you
build and maintain and nurture a culture
where everyone's not in the same room is
becoming easier there are more people
you could talk to if you want to have
engineers abroad
I also think this should be no surprise
to those of you who live and work here
in San Francisco I think we're finally
reaching the point where the cost of
building a company on the coast in San
Francisco New York is becoming a
legitimate issue for startups and
remember I deal with startups that are
typically raising a million dollars or
less for their first round and are very
cost conscious and are very focused on
capital efficiency and I think look
there's some great reasons to be in
these super dense hubs like San
Francisco or New York
there's tons of talent lots of Engineers
product people and designers want to
live there but because talent abundant
and the markets are dense there's a lot
of competition and so while there might
be tons of people you could hire getting
them to come work for your specific
venture is still a challenge I think the
other thing is that the people you hire
they have to be able to afford to live
in the place where you've set up your
company in San Francisco New York have a
really high cost of living and a really
high cost of operation and everything
from salaries and benefits to office
space to the sort of second order
effects of what you need to pay people
so they can have the lifestyle that
they're looking for for themselves and
their families and so I about a third of
the companies we've backed are based
outside of the Bay Area
the one thing I will say is I think that
number is going to increase the one
thing that gives me pause and one thing
we're thinking about as a founder for
those of you who are thinking about
starting a companies elsewhere I think
it's never been easier to start a
company outside the Bay Area I think
there's still the question of how big
you can get in some of these non San
Francisco New York metros can you
attract capital is there enough local
talent or are you committed to building
and growing and becoming an anchor
company in your community I think it's
still early to know whether you can
still build the same scale of company
outside of the Bay Area and the thing
that makes me happy as someone who has
companies that are not all based in San
Francisco so I've come I have
three companies that are based in
Toronto five in Southern California a
dozen in New York two in the Carolinas
one in Tampa one in Baltimore two in
Boston if I had to get on a plane to
visit them all it would be all that I do
and I'm happy to say that in my opinion
the collaboration tools that we've been
talking about since the beginning of the
internet they actually work now you can
use video conferencing reliably it's
cheap you can use it on your phone you
can use it on your laptop you can use it
on your tablet you can use it anywhere
you can use it on the go that to me is a
huge game-changer in terms of face to
face high fidelity conversations we've
got you pick your own flavor of group
based chat makes it really easy for
people in different departments within
the same company or with partners to
communicate regularly in real time huge
game changer in terms of keeping
communication lines open and I think
it's just a lot easier to push push code
to the cloud you don't have to all be
sitting in the same room in order to do
so and these things are finally growing
up and I think I personally been waiting
for a decade for these tools to get to
the point where they're mature enough
that you can actually run your company
on them but I would say the thing I see
companies that I'm doing with wrestle
with most is Wow none of these things
are possible and they can be done the
question is will should you do them is
it the right decision for your startup
and I'm talking to a handful of the
portfolio right now who are thinking
about what I think is the fundamental
divide is do we want to be a centralized
headquarters focused company do we want
to be fully distributed where everybody
works wherever they are kind of a la a
buffer where you've got people
everywhere and there is no central HQ or
do we want a blended model where we have
kind of one or two core offices but
we're willing to incorporate and support
people who are not in one of our hub
offices but work remotely and I think
the big questions here are hiring
remotely when you don't get to interact
with those people face to face every day
is a different skill and it's a
different process it's a different
technique than hiring people that live
and work in the city where the company's
based I think retaining people making
them feel a part of your culture and a
part of the organization when you don't
have that daily in-person interaction is
a challenge it doesn't happen
automatically it requires real effort
and work
and I think it puts a different kind of
strain on management to make sure that
everybody stays in the loop and stays
coordinated because being in a central
office is a crutch you don't have to be
as good about documentation formal
communication you can lean over and chat
with people and building a culture where
the people who are not in headquarters
or when everyone's not in the same place
feel included in the conversations is a
real cultural challenge that you have to
tackle if you're gonna go this way I
think the other piece that's really
changed and the reason I started
precurser is the way you can fundraise
and finance a start-up has really
changed and I'll be honest I'm not sure
that all of these changes are actually
good for you as entrepreneurs I'll tell
you why I think in the old model it was
really simple there were a couple of
really discreet rounds and ways you
financed you've got a little bit of
money from angels or your friends and
family to get started there was no
institutional seed round of two to three
million dollars if you had a good
company you raised the series a you went
series B you got a growth Ronnie went
public the good news was that it was
simple there were only a few steps you
could take in the journey the bad news
was if you didn't fully get all of the
work done to go from angel friends and
family to series a there was no safety
net for your company pretty much died
and shut down or you got a bridge from
your existing investors and I think a
lot of the innovation that's happened to
startup financing is VCS and other and
other financing sources have emerged to
kind of fill in these gaps well you
raise some friends and family money but
you're not quite ready for series a well
we'll give you this new thing called the
seed round which is a two to three
million dollar round that will help you
develop the metrics that you need to get
ready for Series A oh you raise the seed
round you're not quite ready for a
Series A we have this thing called the
seed extension which is another round
that will help you get closer to Series
A and so the good news for you as
founders is there are many many more
sort of off ramps and waypoints for you
to raise money based on the traction and
progress you've made with the business
the downside is all of this creates a
lot more confusion the nomenclature of
what you call these rounds has changed
when I started in the business a big
seed round was a million dollars that
was considered large today a big seed
round is three and a half million
people still call it a seed round three
times as much capital and some of the
firms that used to write that 500k check
into a million dollar round now when I
write one and a half million dollar
checks into a three million dollar round
and they still call themselves seed
firms so it puts the onus on you as
entrepreneurs to understand the changing
business models and venture and now at
last con I saw there over 500
early-stage venture capital firms that's
a lot of firms for you to know index and
figure out if they're right for you in
the world where there were fewer firms
it was just a lot easier to figure out
who you should approach and again I
think it's great to have more options
but more options means more time spent
fundraising and more choice for you the
other thing I think people haven't
really thought about as much is all of
these incremental rounds of fundraising
every time you raise more money you're
selling more of your company and so for
you as founders it means the good news
is you can have this high resolution
fundraising where you're raising a
little bit of money along the way but
the total cumulative dilution to you I
think it's actually probably worse than
it wasn't the old day because now you
sell a little bit of your company a lot
of time a lot of times to a lot of
different people whereas in the old days
you sold a big chunk of your company
every now and then to one or two people
I think the other thing is with more
fundraising this high resolution
fundraising where you have all these
other options it means you as founders
are likely going to spend more of your
time fundraising because there are more
incremental rounds that you could put
together along the way and who here has
gone through the fundraising process to
date hopefully you would all agree that
it's a big distraction from running your
company and building the product and so
the more often you have to press pause
and fundraise the more distraction you
have within your company and I also just
say every six months the milestone to
way way points for getting that new
round done change and last you have more
options other than just VCS
i ce o--'s tokens or cryptocurrency are
the new thing before we had that we had
pre-order campaigns Kickstarter's and
crowdfunding mostly for hardware
companies and we've got things like
patreon and as it say the rebirth of
subscriptions give companies more ways
to raise money directly from your own
customers I think the other thing I
would say that's really changing the way
that I think about
having conversations with startups and
something you should all consider is I
think this whole notion of companies
staying private longer is is the new
norm and I think it's here to stay as
long as the private markets are willing
to provide large amounts of capital to
private venture back startups
this has really profound implications
for how we think about managing
companies incentivizing employees and
how you as founders and entrepreneurs
should think about your own ownership
position I think in a world where
companies didn't stay private very long
you know five to seven years and you go
public a four year option grant with the
one-year cliff and a three year vesting
schedule kind of made sense because the
length of that option was roughly tied
to sort of the useful life of that
private company and you weren't going to
have a company it was private for ten
years now you look at Dropbox uber
Pinterest we have a number of companies
within walking distance from here that
are probably will be private for a
decade before they go public and it's
worth asking in a world where people
could stay that whole time is the
four-year option structure that we put
in place is it the best for the employee
and is it best for you as founders to
offer that and I'm finally beginning to
see some movement and conversation
around that I think the second thing is
for a long time it was taboo for our
founders to sell early it was considered
a poor signal for you to sell a portion
of your ownership in the company before
VCS and other folks had a chance to get
out with company staying private for a
decade VC is like me and founders should
have the opportunity to potentially sell
a little bit along the way and now
there's a ready infrastructure for who
want to sell this is the new thing I
still have friends who've been in
venture their entire career who think
this is a bad thing I think this is this
is just the reality
now if companies are gonna stay private
longer there's going to be more demand
for liquidity from shareholders both
employees and the early investors before
there's a major IPO effect I also think
at some point we're gonna we're gonna
learn to stay in private actually pay
off
I think the thesis has been if you stay
private longer you can build more you
could get the product ready you can sort
of give the organization ready for the
rigors of being a public company and
when you finally do IPO
you'll be better off it's unclear
we've had some IPOs this year that have
not done great and in some cases where
the current trading price is below the
last private market valuation which is
not good for the shareholders of the
company it's not good for the employees
so I think with this next batch of
companies we're gonna learn whether this
notion that staying private longer is a
good thing is in fact true so I wanted
to leave you with a few final thoughts
and a couple things to consider because
I'm wrestling with these issues and I
don't claim to have answers to all of
them myself the good news for you is
that most of I think most of the
playbooks around what you do in venture
and how you build a good ambitious
company I think they're pretty stale and
that's a good thing for you because when
the playbooks really work anyone can
apply them and it's easy to do I think
we're in a moment in time where
technology is finally unlocking a lot of
promises for startups and I think the
companies that really grapple and
wrestle with these issues have an
advantage I think it's worth saying that
everything I've just told you is not
widely held or widely believed by every
other VC or pundit out there some people
will still tell you you got to build a
company in San Francisco and you got to
have everyone under one roof do not run
these experiments it will destroy your
company I think the good news is you're
all here because you're trying to do
things differently and I really believe
that this changing technology
infrastructure combined with this
changing financial landscape gives you
all the opportunity and the license to
try to build companies that look and
feel different and the last thing I'll
leave you with is most of the benefits
are gonna go to people who do these
experiments early by the time we resolve
decentralized teams headquarters versus
no headquarters fully revoked by the
time there's a consensus somebody else
will take an advantage of the
opportunity to experiment and learn and
captured all that benefit so if you're
gonna wait for the dust to settle and
all these things that's fine but I think
you're missing out on a big opportunity
and I think I would encourage all of you
to run some cool
with your own startups around how you
structure your teams and how you think
about fundraising because there's never
been a better time I think to break the
mold and think differently so I want to
thank you for giving me a chance to kind
of share some things I've been wrestling
with as an investor and thank you very
much for the time I really appreciate it
[Applause]
